ODIN is a national program of the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) and the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association (NRECA) that provides a secure environment for the exchange of outage information between utilities. 
 
ODIN has been developed to provide utilities with a common outage information exchange framework that can be used to meet their individual needs for data sharing and exchange. ODIN enables utilities to share outage data with one another to support their operations, planning, and other business needs. 
 
ODIN is designed to be a highly flexible framework that utilities can use to share outage data in the ways that they need. For example, utilities can use ODIN to exchange outage data with each other on a near real-time basis, on a pre-planned schedule, or on an as-needed basis. ODIN also provides utilities with the ability to share outage data with other utilities in a secure manner that meets the needs of the participating utilities. 
 
ODIN is based on the Common Information Model (CIM) standard developed by the International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC). The CIM is a data model for the electrical power industry that provides a common representation of electrical power industry data. The CIM is used by utilities to represent their data in a way that is compatible with other utilities and other power industry standards. 
 
ODIN is designed to be compatible with the CIM standard, which means that utilities can use ODIN to share outage data with other utilities that are also using the CIM standard. This compatibility enables utilities to share outage data with other utilities in a way that is compatible with the CIM standard and the other utilities' data models. 
 
ODIN is also designed to be compatible with other power industry standards, such as the Open Network Protocol (ONP) and the National Information Exchange Model (NIEM). This compatibility enables utilities to share outage data with other utilities that are also using these standards.

Outage Data Initiative Nationwide (ODIN) 
 
The Outage Data Initiative Nationwide (ODIN) is a nationwide outage data standardization initiative that will provide a single source of truth for outage data across the United States. ODIN is a collaborative effort between the National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL) and the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI). 
 
The Outage Data Initiative Nationwide (ODIN) will provide a common framework for sharing outage data. The ODIN outage data standardization initiative will enable the sharing of outage data between utilities, regulators, emergency responders, and the public. 
 
ODIN is a collaborative effort between the National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL) and the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI). 
 
NETL has been developing a Common Information Model (CIM) based on the International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC) standard 61968-3 for outage data for several years. EPRI is leading the development of the outage data standardization initiative. 
 
The ODIN outage data standardization initiative will enable the sharing of outage data between utilities, regulators, emergency responders, and the public. 
 
 
Why does ODIN matter? 
 
The ODIN outage data standardization initiative will enable the sharing of outage data between utilities, regulators, emergency responders, and the public.

to the Outage Data Initiative Nationwide (ODIN) for the transmission and distribution outage information from the utilities to the ODIN. 
 
ODIN is a free, open-source platform for managing and visualizing outages. It is designed to help utilities, emergency responders, and the public work together to better understand and respond to power outages. 
 
The ODIN platform is being built by a consortium of utilities, open-source developers, and academic researchers. It is supported by the National Science Foundation and is freely available to all utilities, emergency responders, and the public. 
 
The ODIN platform is based on the Common Information Model (CIM) standard developed by the IEC. The CIM standard provides a common data model for power system devices, equipment, and processes. The CIM standard is widely used by utilities, vendors, and researchers to represent power system information. 
 
The ODIN platform uses the CIM standard to represent outage information. Utilities can use the ODIN platform to send outage information to the ODIN platform. Emergency responders can use the ODIN platform to view outage information. The public can use the ODIN platform to view outage information. 
 
The ODIN platform is designed to be highly scalable and resilient. It is built on a distributed architecture that allows it to handle large amounts of data and to recover quickly from failures. 
 
The ODIN platform is being developed by a team of open-source developers. The team is working on a number of projects to improve the ODIN platform. These projects include: 
 
- A data pipeline that automatically ingests and transforms outage data from utilities into the ODIN platform 
- A data model that represents outage information in a way that is compatible with the CIM standard 
- A visualization tool that allows emergency responders to view outage information in a map 
- A web application that allows the public to view outage information 
 
The ODIN platform is being used by a number of utilities and emergency responders. It is also being used by researchers to study outage data. 
 
The ODIN platform is an open-source project. Anyone can contribute to the project. The project is licensed under the Apache License

The standard also specifies a protocol for exchanging outage information between utilities and other parties.

1. Outage Data Initiative Nationwide (ODIN) 
 
The Outage Data Initiative Nationwide (ODIN) is a collaboration among electric utility companies and software vendors to provide a national outage data sharing platform that will allow participating utilities to share outage data. This initiative is designed to assist utilities to meet the requirements of the North American Electric Reliability Corporation (NERC) Critical Infrastructure Protection (CIP) standards, specifically CIP-014-1 and CIP-014-2. 
 
The Outage Data Initiative Nationwide (ODIN) provides a secure, reliable and scalable outage sharing platform that enables utilities to share standardized outage data. The Outage Data Initiative Nationwide (ODIN) provides a mechanism for utilities to send and receive standardized outage data.

Step 2: Sharing standardized outage data using CIM IEC 61968-3 

Step 2 is to share standardized outage data using CIM IEC 61968-3. This step will be repeated for each outage transmission.

to the Outage Data Initiative Nationwide (ODIN) platform. This guide describes the steps to follow to submit standardized outage data from a utility or other provider to ODIN. The guide is intended for developers, data analysts, and other technical personnel who are responsible for implementing this data contribution process. 
 
What is ODIN? 
 
ODIN is a platform that allows for the collection and analysis of standardized outage data from multiple electric utilities and other organizations. ODIN was created in 2019 as a collaboration between the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) and the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association (NRECA). It is designed to help utilities and other organizations make better decisions and improve outage performance by collecting and analyzing standardized outage data. 
 
The ODIN platform uses a common data model based on the Common Information Model (CIM) IEC 61968-3, which is an international standard for representing outage data. The CIM IEC 61968-3 standard provides a common language for describing outage events and their impacts. 
 
Why contribute data to ODIN? 
 
There are many benefits to contributing data to ODIN. By sharing data with ODIN, utilities and other organizations can access valuable insights and analysis that can help them improve outage performance and make better decisions. 
 
Contributing data to ODIN can also help utilities and other organizations meet their compliance requirements. Many states and regulatory agencies require utilities to report outage data in a standardized format, and ODIN can help utilities meet these requirements. 
 
How to contribute data to ODIN 
 
Contributing data to ODIN is a simple process that involves four main steps: 
 
1. Register a new account 
2. Share standardized outage data using CIM IEC 61968-3 
3. Send outage information to ODIN securely 
4. Follow up with ODIN 
 
Step 1: Register a new account
